Definition: In this task, you receive a public comment from online platforms. It is expected that you divide the comment into two classes: disagree and agree. Classify the comment as disagree if it expresses strong disagreement. Classify the comment as agree if no strong disagreement is expressed.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Weak and pathetic border enforcement.  Why bother with a border if this defines our Country.  Canada has become a pathetic weakling, likes its ruling party.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment expresses its strong disagreement with Canada.

sick to death of looking at his bigoted mug.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment does not express any sign of disagreement.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: It must suck to be this scared of life
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment expresses its strong disagreement with life.
This comment does not express any sign of disagreement.

Comment: Gender equality, freedom of expression, LGBT rights, maternal health, reproductive rights - all these liberal values championed by Canada are treated with (often violent) hostility in countries where face covering is common. The face covering is not independent of a regressive belief system that subjugates women, it is a symbol of that belief system. European countries have implement bans of full face covering in public, why is that? Bill C62 aims to restrict a cultural symbol that is part and parcel of a regressive belief system that encourages social division and segregation. Ideas of "modesty" are fundamentally incompatible with Canadian values of gender equality, it has absolutely nothing to do with cultural relativism - it is simply a function of progress. European attempts to appease the culture associated with face coverings only empowered the fundamentalists, why should Canada emulate Europe's failures?

Comment: I've visited and lived in Eugene for the last 2+ years as a transplant from an East Coast city.  In this short time, I have observed this city in-fight, talk ad nauseum, and have complete analysis paralysis over a number of development opportunities.  After all is said and done, what remains from all this talking?  I've noted increasing crime in the area, absurd downtown regulations, and lack of some fundamental smart/safety services (salt the damn roads).  I like Eugene and believe the natural environment is a blessing but as others have reiterated, Eugene government needs to escape the haze of cloud cover that exists here for 7 months of the year and take some action.  On the East Coast, we'd have built on the downtown site 4 times over by now and have a real plan for the EWEB property.  Hell, even my 8 year old wonders why can't the government decide what to do?  Isn't the slogan here enough?  Take some action.  For christ sake, Eugene, stop talking about it.  Just do it.

Comment: I have to agree that people don't read policies.  I have had friends tell me what a great deal they got on their insurance.  When I express concern about them not being covered they often pull out their policy.  This is when I point out that they are not covered for anywhere near the value of either the house or the contents.  

If you make large purchases you have to make sure 1. you document it and 2. you make sure you are covered for it on your policy.  You also have to make sure you are covered for the value of your house - not what you paid for it as rebuilding is often more expensive.  This is a lesson learned by the Fort Mac home owners - many were under insured.

I am lucky I have a great broker that does ask questions - and I have also learned on my job as I handle my corporate policies as well (there I get an annual questionnaire).  As for the comment that it is time consuming to update your insurer - it takes 5 mins to phone the details in.

Comment: I am talking about a very different technology.  No till is a variant of the thousands of year old technology which saves fuel with perhaps less erosion, water loss or CO2 release but with many time more herbicide but the whole plant still grow to get the end product whether it might be corn oil or cattle feed so the farmer is still locked into a growing season with hazards and the large evaporation of an open field.
Something like hydroponics or an algae bioreactor is a small area in a basic closed loop system so little water is used, no herbicides, and it can be continuous production 365 days a year with the output being corn oil or cattle feed without intermediate steps. It is as big a change as going from hunting and gathering to established agriculture.

Comment: Regarding buying US stocks and currency risk:  I agree with your analysis of the stock and dividend values in US$ and Canadian$.   However, you do  not discuss the risk over time of changes in relative currency valuations.  For example, my Canadian stock values have depreciated 25% because  I, a US investor,  bought them when the C$ was at par with the US$.   Conversely, a Canadian investor buying US stocks at this time incurs the risk that, when he sells the US stocks,  the US$ might depreciate relative to the Canadian$, and the dividend would also lose value .
Again, it is more complicated than that, and there are mitigating factors.  But it's something to consider.

Comment: Mr. Cole, you need to read the statute.  The realized earnings of the Permanent Fund (PF) are NOT fed directly into the Earnings Reserve.  Instead, 21% of the total earnings over 5 years are distributed 50/50 into the Earnings Reserve (ER) and the Permanent Fund Dividend distribution fund (PFD).  The ER (not including the PFD funding) is then reinvested in more liquid instruments than the Corpus of the PF does not need to be touched and can keep growing for the future.  The ER is available to the legislature (through a two-thirds consensus vote) at any time for NECESSARY government functions.  So, if they want to cover the $2.8 billion deficit with these funds this year, they can.  Do I want them to?  NO.  I want them to use a combination of cuts and ER funds to work for 3 years on reducing the ENTIRE governmental budget, regardless of UGF, DF or Administrative funding name.

Comment: Cap 'n Trade is about the LEAST effective possible means to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.  The purpose is primarily to be obscure, hard to understand and to allow for politicians to "help" industries or companies they like and "hurt" industries or companies they don't like.

If, by some odd chance, greenhouse gas emissions manage to go down in the process that is a bonus, but that certainly is *NOT* the primary goal of a Cap 'n Trade system.

If the goal is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions the solution is a SIMPLE, transparent and equal tax on greenhouse gas emissions, one that REPLACES (rather than supplements) the numerous existing taxes on fossil fuels.

If government is doing anything more complex than that they are doing so for reasons other than to reduce greenhouse gases.

Comment: Actually, that story is a complete fabrication: a myth made up by people wanting to blame the US government for the demise of Native Americans.   it is just like the completely false stories of the government giving Indians blankets infected with smallpox. Yes, the Buffalo were nearly exterminated by over hunting.   But that happened to many different species in that time period, as the government had no restrictions of any kind on hunting back then.   Wolves were hunted to extinction in every state except Alaska.   The Passenger Pigeon used to be the most numerous bird in all of North America.   But the lack of any government regulations or restrictions of any kind on hunting led to its extinction too.

Shooting Buffalo became a big tourist industry.  People found it fun sport to kill them.

Comment: I recently flew to Europe from Vancouver with Air Canada.  As I am 6'2", I am willing to spend extra to have a little more room on these flights

I brought this to the attention of Air Canada and asked them to provide a seat with more leg room and they went on a mantra about how the incremental fee was for either more leg room or being closer to the front of the jet.  I told them I could care less if it was mid, front or back, I only wanted leg room and I had made my payment for these seats.  I was given the run around.

I am not sure if Air Canada will refund the incremental fee (wait and see if they process a credit). I recognize this is a lesser issue than being kicked off of flights altogether, but just another example of the BS airlines get away with.

Comment: What is metro? A metro is a public transit network of elevated or subway lines that serve a metropolitan area. The network can extend in all directions from the city center, out to the suburbs. The different lines of the network intersect at hubs where people can get on other lines to their destination. Bangkok has an elevated network of lines, similar to our metro, due to Bangkok being on the Chao Phraya river which floods the city. Most cities in Europe have metro lines that are subways in the historic centers, and become above grade on the newer outskirts. Many cities have numerous network lines. New York, Boston, San Francisco, keep adding more lines as the demand increases for metro transit. Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil have beautiful metro stations. Shanghai, Beijing also have extensive metro networks. Paris has a metro stations that are hubs for connection to high speed rail lines to major cities in France and other European cities. Most metros have airport stations

Comment: Andrew I agree that averaging 8.5% on a risk free basis is not going to happen.  However, it is quite possible to get reasonably close with only a marginally elevated total risk level.  My own portfolio average is around 6% yield (current value not YOC).  But that includes a portion of my portfolio that doesn't pay a dividend - notably BRK as well as some long term provincial strips bought years ago.  If I was to convert everything to dividend paying stocks my yield would likely be pushing 7%.  Which includes a solid core base in the 3 - 5% range, a smaller chunk in the 6 - 8% range and the rest in the 8 - 10% range.   

Indeed probably not for everyone - but still a 5% dividend yield with the remained made up of capital is still a pretty good balance.  The withdrawn capital can always be reinvested back into dividend stocks in a cash account or TFSA.

Comment: Aloha UncleSam: Happy to clarify Brett's relationship to us and if you look in our archives you'll find a story about it when he first started. Brett is like any of our regular columnists: Denby Fawcett, Ian Lind, Peter Apo, Neal Milner, Kathy Kozak, Luke Evslin, Ethan Porter and I'm probably forgetting someone. They are on "on staff" so that's why they are not listed in the staff box. They are contractors or freelancers who we pay on a per-piece basis. However, they do go through the editing process as any other staff writer would. Community Voices are like op-eds in what you call "a real newspaper."  Submissions by a variety of voices and they do not get paid so we edit them only for style and grammar etc. Brett's column has a title, "Reader Rep," not because he represents CB but because it gets at what he is trying to write about ... helping readers better understand how the media works. That is his only subject so it has a name, like Health Beat or Hawaii Teacher.

Comment: Implicit in Ms. Ambrose's statement is the assumption (a reasonable one) that the new US Administration will be introducing strong measures that favour its investors and speculators (at least if you disregard the dangers entailed in removing safeguards against environmental degradation, unsavory business and speculative practices, financial bubbles and growing inequalities in wealth and income in society) and the assumption (a dangerous one) that Canada should be adopting similar measures to keep pace with US economic developments.

Clearly, the Liberal Government faces challenges in the face of the yet unclear direction of US public policy, but in navigating through these challenging waters its best course will not be to simply follow in the wake of the US.  Likewise, the Conservative Party should be clear in its presentation of policy alternatives for Canada and be careful, in doing so, that it doesn't blindly ape the Trump phenomena.

Comment: That question has not been answered.

General population studies cannot be applied to a specifically filtered group - which is what Eg: Soh does.     So to answer the question, you would need to conduct a study on the population in question (eg:   Software Engineers).     Even that would only give you an "average".    Individual variance would mean that there will always be individuals (male or female) who deviate from the norm.

It is ALWAYS the goal of any company (particularly a tech company) to hire exceptional employees (those who deviate from the norm).     Thus, studies which talk about "average" are not relevant to a company looking for NOT average.     i.e.    Google is NOT hiring to conform to a general population average.    They are looking for people who deviate above the norm.

So the question is kind of irrelevant.

Comment: Busting street dealers is virtually pointless since (at least in the DTES) they're usually users themselves being paid in cash + drugs to sling gear on the corner; detain one and another takes his place the next morning.

The sooner we accept this and move toward a regulated production and distribution system of all recreational drugs--which are vastly safer when made to pharmaceutical standards--the more lives and money and woe we'll save.

Comment: "In a capitalist society, money moves to places where it gets the best returns. In a socialist society, money gets frivolously wasted and capital gets confiscated by burdensome tax rates to pay for poor policy decisions."

What? Okay, I get the part about capital seeking the best returns. But Canada has never been a "socialistic" society. Instead, since WWII it's largely functioned on the basis of what's called a "mixed-market" economy, where governments function and regulate to promote and protect the public interest. Our public healthcare system is in fact vastly more efficient than the American model in economic terms and abandoning the government's oversight and regulatory role helped to precipitate the 2008/09 crash in the U.S., leading to negative global consequences. The author's other big concerns appear to focus on taxation and debt, and those are clearly valid issues, but let's get the terminology straight and abandon ideological pretense to get this right going forward.

"1909 Athenæum 13 Mar. 325/3 Those whose sense of justice..is not impaired by prejudice or ‘xenophoby’."

Comment: I was actually more referencing what has been done in Laffer's name rather than what he actually said. His actual theory (which I understand) remains untested. Hardly any country has ever actually been at the peak of the Laffer curve but even if one had been - none has ever actually done what he actually proposed. Cutting taxes was NOT what Laffer proposed. Cutting taxes only on the rich was REALLY not what he proposed.
Laffer proposed a tax cut for EVERYBODY with short term spending cuts that match the tax cuts. Cutting on only the rich does NOT stimulate economic growth at all - they are already rich, you get MORE done by cutting on the middle class and poor and possibly enabling some wannabe entrepeneurs to afford to start a business.  
Not cutting spending means the whole plan falls appart.
Making the cuts permanent destroys it all - because it's harms outweigh any gains you can make. The cuts MUST be written in law to be temporary - ONLY until revenues recover.

Comment: The researchers, who examined the brains of former football players, found that 99 per cent of the players they studied had CTE.... The study subjects were not chosen at random; rather, the players (or their families) donated their brains because of suspicious symptoms.
------------
That is no small problem with the study.  It reviewed the brains of a very selective group individuals who had suspicious symptoms, enough that their brains were donated for research: the study found that those who appeared to suffer some form of trauma had CTE.  How does this relate to the impact that football has had on those that displayed no trauma. i.e. the vast majority of those who played? Perhaps the vast majority of young football players have not and will never suffer from CTE. A wider non exclusive study is required.

Comment: Personally, I think certain types of businesses should be allowed to discriminate as they see fit. .

.

.
Anti-discrimination laws like this don't stop discrimination, they only hide it. A plan like this could bring it out into the open and open the door for real social justice. Know your enemy.

Comment: "do those individuals that have illegally settled into our own Nation, enjoy the same protections under our own Constitution, or not?"
As I stated before the Constitution protects them roughly similarly to non-citizens that are here legally.  The fact that they committed a crime does not change the limitations on government action under the Constitution.
"The fact that they are here illegally, first and foremost, does, and should not, afford them said protection within our own Constitution"
You are still thinking about the Constitution in the wrong way.  The Constitution does not grant or bestow protections, ie. produce positive rights.  It limits government action, ie. produces negative restrictions.  For example, there is no right to privacy under the words of the Constitution.  It is not specifically "granted" or "bestowed."  However, the limitations on government actions in other areas, e.g. protection from unreasonable search/seizure, grounds such substantive due process rights.

Comment: The adviser's recommendation on how to use debt is good, as far as it goes. Melanie would be better served to stay out of debt in future. She would not get much benefit from borrowing to invest with the small sums she works with. 3.2% on a LOC of $12,254 costs about $392 a year in interest. Interest costs after tax drop to about $270 for debt is used for investments. Savings of $120 may not be worth the aggravation.

Once her debts are gone, about 8 months after her mortgage is gone, she would have about $16,000 a year to invest, plus what she is putting in her TFSA/RRSP's now. Assuming her total RRSP/TFSA contribution room increases by $10,000 a year, if she contributes all she can she will use up her current and future contribution room in under four years.

I expect Melanie will be like many other people who find themselves flush with cash late in life. She will want to spend some of it on fun and games. In this regard her vacation budget is way too low.

Comment: Motley:  I know this comment is to some degree (I don't know how much of a degree) tongue in cheek.  However, many folks my age (73) are struggling to survive financially.  Many of their adult children are not in a position to provide much help to them.  I've seen seriors write checks to the pharmacy for several hundred dollars for medications which Midicare doesn't cover.  We've had elderly tenants who can barely pay their rent.  We've had tenants whose rent we didn't raise for ten or more years, knowing that they simply couldn't afford the increase.  

Please don't consider this "whining" (personally we're "holding our own") but, for many seniors, being both elderly and really poor is not much fun.  

I enjoy your comments and the many exchanges we've had over time.  However, I feel the issue of poverty among seniors is "no laughing matter."  thanks, Gary

Comment: Dunsmuir and Schneider write: “The Fed’s preferred measure of underlying inflation has retreated to 1.5 per cent, from 1.8 per cent earlier this year, and has run below the central bank’s 2 per cent target for more than five years.” This is false. The US Fed targets the personal consumption expenditures price index (PCEPI). It was at 2.2% in February, but has since dropped to 1.7% in April. Except for February 2017 it has only exceeded its two percent target from January to April 2012, i.e. in the month the US Fed officially adopted an inflation target rate with the PCEPI as its indicator. Dunsmuir and Schneider are referencing the PCEPI excluding food and energy (PCEPILFE), a core PCEPI measure, and the preferred one of the US Fed, although they also follow a trimmed mean core measure quite closely. It did fall from an inflation rate of 1.8% in January and February to 1.5% in April and has never been at or above the two percent target from January 2012 forward.

If people then choose Canada first, knowing those are the terms, great!

Comment: I beg to differ with the author. In Canada, tax money has followed the child to whatever school he or she attends since the Quebec Act of 1774.  We moved to Colorado from Alberta, where tax money followed children to district-run, Catholic, charter, other religious, and privately run non-sectarian schools.  All of these schools could choose to use the model provincial curriculum which was tighly aligned to provincial academic standards. And all students who received taxpayer financing were required to take the Provincial Achievement Tests (now only required in Grades 6 and 9, because in a province that has banned grading on a curve, teacher assigned grades provide very powerful feedback). Alberta's PISA scores are among the best in the world; when converted to NAEP scores, Alberta outperforms Colorado by a large margin. So, Ms. Spiegel, just how has the use of a voucher system adversely affected education results in Alberta?

Comment: That’s an oversimplification of the issues that Archbishop Lefebvre himself raised.

Lefebvre advocated pragmatic religious tolerance rather than so-called “religious liberty”, which in one sense the Church had always condemned when declarations of the "rights of man" were made against the authority of God.

The final document the Council issued essentially adopted Lefebvre’s pragmatic religious tolerance but called it “religious liberty”, leaving some confusion.

Lefebvre’s view is consistent with the Church’s maxim “error has no rights”.

Like “Outside the Church there is no salvation”, everyone needs to be on the same page as to the meaning of the terms used.

Comment: Mark, there's been no published evidence in support of the AGW hypothesis. I can't cite negative (a lack of) evidence, that's the whole point; a lack of evidence. There's just nothing positive, no confirming observation.

Physics, and specifically thermodynamics, are evidence based sciences. If a person advances a hypothesis, they're required to present a repeatable experiment that supports it, or at the very least repeatable observation of the natural world. That hasn't happened. 

Can you cite a single published paper that has repeatably shown a causal relation between CO2 and temperature? No. You can't. None exist.

It's not the job of a critique to prove the AGW hypothesis wrong; it's the job of the investigator to prove it right. That's the fundamental mechanism of the scientific method.

Comment: And physicians still tend to practice in the manner they prefer (patterns/volumes of diagnostic testing, variations in treatments). We already know this. But more data collection has done little, if anything, to significantly change these practice preferences. 

Time and time again, context and culture have been identified as the critical determinants. And much of this was discovered long before the advent of high technology and sophisticated analytics. 

I do suggest you look over some of the research from The Dartmouth Institute I cited above. Years of data - same old story. US findings, but one can easily assume Canada is not much different (except for lower volumes due to more restrained capacity). 

There are already systems and administration in health care. If additional administration and data does not improve care or reduce costs, then it represents a dis-economy. It becomes a show piece suggesting greater efficiency or higher quality without the actual outcome.

Comment: 5 Star is united only in opposition to the many deficiencies in Italy's economic, social and political institutions.  It has no common program to reform those institutions as Government.  Instead, it provides a political home for the widest range of contemporary political thought without synthesizing all this together into a workable reformation program. The default position thus is nihilism although it appears to avoid the authoritarian and xenophobic tendencies of populists in northern and Atlantic Europe currently.

Along with charlatans & incompetents, it undoubtedly includes many well-meaning public spirited individuals who could, as individuals, make a useful contribution to public life. 

However, like Italy itself, 4 Star appears to embrace both cutting edge modern and centuries' old divisive tendencies (the ultra avant-guard and obscurantist) of ancient regional societies that are much divided internally and with each other and have not coalesced as one State or Nation.

Comment: Rohr 3

The Wisdom section of the Hebrew Scriptures includes the books of Job, Ecclesiastes, the Song of Songs, and many of the Psalms. Wisdom literature reveals an ability to be patient with mystery and contradictions—and the soul itself. Wise people have always passed through a major death to their egocentricity. This is the core meaning of transformation.
We have to go through interior deaths to reach the third stage of wisdom. Only here does contemplation and nondual thinking become possible; we can begin to learn to live with mystery and paradox and to develop true compassion. If stage one is order and stage two is disorder, then stage three is the final goal of reorder. There is no way around stage two! It is what Paul calls “the folly of the cross” (1 Corinthians ‪1:18‬). Conservatives tend to stop at stage one, liberals tend to get trapped in stage two, but only stage three is the full risen life of Christ.

Comment: Oh no. Not that "losing an hour of sleep" nonsense again. That's why the time change is done on Saturday night. You won't lose sleep unless you're foolish enough to use an alarm clock on a Sunday morning. (Apologies to those who must work Sundays.)

Comment: How much does this facility cost Alaskan taxpayers? I mean, I like cool stuff too, but here in Fairbanks, we've decided our local governments would eat our paychecks to provide us with this "cool" stuff and we wouldn't be able to afford to do anything else. So, while the "dome" is broken, maybe people ought to pause and ask, how much does it cost and is it possible that a private company could offer something that doesn't collapse under snow load (which Anchorage gets a lot, I think). It might cost the individual users more money upfront, but it would likely cost far less to operate were a private company with a profit motive to offer the same facility. And, guaranteed, because they have to stay open to make money, they would not allow it to collapse under snow load.

Oh, and by the way, while the dome is collapsed and unusable, you might want to realize that taxpayers are still paying for it. That wouldn't be the case with a private company.

Comment: The National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) just released their EV infrastructure analysis. (https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy17osti/69031.pdf)

The NREL found that a fleet of 15 million EVs would need 400 corridor DCFC stations (2,500 plugs) spaced 70 miles apart across the U.S. Interstate Highway System. 

"Results suggest that relatively few corridor DCFC stations could enable long-distance BEV travel between U.S. cities, where vehicles are concentrated. Under most scenarios, the number of required stations is similar to the number of corridor DCFC stations already established by Tesla or the number planned by Electrify America within the next two years."

Comment: 2/2
This could be flipped into either a tri-level or four-leveled democracy over perhaps several decades without  excessive disruption. The key element should be a diocesan synod composed of all clergy and elected representative from every parish, with the bishop as president of the synod, but democratically subject to his synod for legislation.

The bishop would continue to appoint pastors, who would become presidents of each parish synod composed of elected parishioners.

If the Bishop of Rome were elected by all 5000 or so bishops, we would have a tri-level democracy. I would prefer to see diocese grouped into provinces of about 25 dioceses, and then have the bishops of each province elect one of their number to sit on a permanent synod in Rome. This permanent synod would elect the Bishop of Rome, and the pope would rule as prime minister (PM) of the synod.  The  PM forms the government (curia), but all legislative authority would remain with the Roman synod.

Comment: William,

There is a phenomenon that I have observed and experienced in many successful endeavors - we tend to become a "victim of our own success".

It is precisely BECAUSE the SDA church has been successful, that we need to intentionally and constructively address these issues, which otherwise become BARRIERS to future success.

In a very peculiar sense, we have a built-in contradiction in Adventist thinking.  Individually and institutionally, "success" constitutes reaching the point of irrelevance - when Jesus returns to take us ALL home the SDA church and its various institutions will cease to exist!

LDS and JW theologies ascribe a special role in the Afterlife, for their adherents.  Some Adventists do likewise with their emphasis on "last generation" or 144,000 motifs.

If we eschew these models (see Mt 20:1-16) then we must agree that the blessing accruing to Adventists is the blessing of serving others.  Our notion of "success" must change from "gaining" to "giving".

.
No, whoever wrote this does not understand the realities of transit networks.
.
Any kind of network system increases the value at all points on the network as a function of the destination combinations made possible by the network, and, roughly, the percentage of the community that is served by that network.  
.
This is why the oil companies do not want transit lines - and particularly not dedicated right-of-way transit lines - to link up.  That is what the political fight was about in Brampton.
.

Comment: Where did you get your law degree, Trump University?   Here is the Alaska Statutes'  definition of  what you call "accomplice" liability (not the usual term in our state):

Legal accountability based upon the conduct of another.  A person is legally accountable for the conduct of another constituting an offense if[,] ... with intent to promote or facilitate the commission of the offense, the person ... solicits the other to commit the offense[,] or ... aids or abets the other in planning or committing the offense[.]  AS 11.16.110.

Note that there is a requirement of specific intent to aid the offense--not just carelessness that might have made it easier for someone else to commit it.  The operative verbs are "solicit," "aid" and "abet"--all designate concrete actions taken with the required specific intent.  Our criminal law does not use the terms "enable" or "enabling."

Comment: Boo-hoo for the real estate agents.  The complaints from Mr. Hudak have more to do with the impact to the agents, who have enjoyed a bull-market in home sales for decades in the GTA and have come to think of this year-over-year growth in sales and prices as "normal".  Agents have done great for themselves especially as prices go up (remember, they are paid a percentage of the sale price) but nothing goes on forever.  Steps taken to cool the market are necessary because if the market crashes, it will not be the real-estate agents that will have to bear the fallout.  Over-extended buyers losing their home, mortgage insurance firms (including the government backed one), the banks, and if it is a very bad situation, the government (which means taxpayers) which guarantees the banks will all be on the victims.  The economy in general will take a big hit.  Mr. Hudak's job is to represent the agents and their interests: He is doing just that, so ignore every word he says.

Comment: "A 2006 paper by Philip N.S. Rumney in the Cambridge Law Journal offers a review of studies of false reporting in the US, New Zealand and the UK. Rumney draws two conclusions from his review of literature. First, the police continue to misapply the "no-crime" or "unfounding" criteria. Studies by Kelly et al. (2005), Lea et al. (2003), HMCPSI/HMIC (2002), Harris and Grace (1999), Smith (1989), and others found that police decisions to no-crime were frequently dubious and based entirely on the officer's personal judgment. Rumney notes that some officers seem to "have fixed views and expectations about how genuine rape victims should react to their victimization." He adds that "qualitative research also suggests that some officers continue to exhibit an unjustified scepticism of rape complainants, while others interpret such things as lack of evidence or complaint withdrawal as 'proof' of a false allegation."- Wikipedia

The problem appears real, and not confined to Canada.

Comment: Thank you for the great discussion on language immersion programs. There are school districts such as Lexington SC that combine elementary through high school immersion programs with intensive world language programs for ALL students beginning in sixth grade. Lexington is on track to have all their students graduate with proficiency in a second language. Our Eugene-based language assessment company, Avant Assessment conducts proficiency assessments in Lexington as it does in Eugene. Lexington shows that it is possible to provide effective language programs for all students. 

One way to increase graduation rates in Oregon is to do what Washington and other sates do - award competency-based credits to students who demonstrate proficiency in the  heritage language skills that they developed at home. A Gates Foundation funded study by Education NW in the Seattle area showed that this program increased graduation rates among heritage Spanish speaking students by 5.26%.

Comment: From a strictly rational perspective, we do not know the details of what occurred, nor the future impact. We don't know whether or to what extent the girls will be traumatized, nor do we know what Craig's future will hold as a result of his conviction. 

Without that information, we cannot know if the sentence was too lenient or too harsh, so we look for a compromise that we think is consistent with the circumstances and probable outcomes. It isn't perfect, but that's how our criminal justice system works. 

As far as sex crimes are concerned, it is possible that lifelong registration for nonviolent first offenses (there is no evidence that he used force) is too severe a punishment, that it means the person can never fully recover. But, we have to balance that against the interests of potential future victims, so it is reasonable to err on the conservative side.

Comment: The author is right to draw a link between this incident and the growth in the wealth gap that is occurring in the UK and other western industrialized countries, including Canada. While London's finance class and rich expats build their iceberg townhouses and glimmering office buildings and condominiums, less fortunate social housing residents have seen their safety concerns largely ignored by government, with tragic results. 

In this time of gross wealth inequality rivaling that witnessed during the Gilded Age, the responsible thing for government to do is step in more aggressively to provide basic security to those in poverty. With respect to housing, this would involve augmenting property taxes on London's most expensive properties and using that money to ensure social housing lives up to basic safety standards. As long as government does not respond to the growing crisis through these types of reasonable measures, class resentments will continue to build.

There are many more including the excitement of alums like myself to get back on campus. I can take my family around, go show them my old campus. I'm certainly much more interested in donating to my university after going back to campus specifically to see the progress on the stadium and seeing how much they've done to improve the campus, it's really impressive. Comment: "The good news for Colorado is that most restless renters are searching somewhere else along the Front Range."

Written as if a journalist who's been living here for three days already.  

NO, that isn't "good news." Urban sprawl along the Front Range is fueled by the cheap land rush euphoria that settles into a hangover of increasingly long commutes, pollution, inadequate water reserves and inordinate infrastructure demands. 

Worse yet, the automobile becomes the only means of transportation, and the cookie cutter malls that spring up with oodles of parking scream for everybody over the age of sixteen to have their own car or they won't be able to overcome the suburban isolation. 

Denver IS getting some improved planning, to be sure, but we've long since reached a population tipping point at which urban sprawl should have been curbed by sensible local political leadership. The Californication of the Centennial State will go on until we ruin the reason we settled here originally.

Comment: Quadrupling the number of oil tankers  entering and exiting the port of Vancouver every month drastically increased the possibility of a major and catastrophic oil spill.
That increased traffic will also mean more air (and noise) pollution as those ships burn mainly cheap bunker oil, which will affect the general health of people living in the surrounding areas where those tankers are going to operate.
As I wrote previously, shipping Canadian heavy crude oil to Asia or other foreign countries has been qualified as "uneconomical" by most traders involved in that business.  Canadian oil producers can actually use U.S. port facilities to ship their crude oil to other countries (U.S. law allows for exports of Canadian oil as long as they aren't mingled with U.S. products). Around two million barrels of mostly heavy oil from Canada's oil sands have been exported from the U.S. Gulf Coast in 2014. Canada's crude oil exports in 2104 was around 2.85 million barrels "per day".

Comment: The uproar was about the editorial writer who said there is no such thing as cultural appropriation.  He then defines cultural appropriation as writing about people from other cultures-- which is not what aboriginal people mean by it.  The article is based on a straw man fallacy.

When Gord Downie wrote his film about Charlie Wenjak, he was praised by the some of the same aboriginal people who are in an uproar now -- because he did his research and talked with aboriginal people who had an interest to make sure the story he told was an accurate and respectful representation, not cultural appropriation.

When Emily Carr painted images of aboriginal totem poles, she went to the communities and learned about their significance before painting them -- and in her unique style that was European influenced.  That's not appropriation, it's sharing.  

And that's a whole different thing that that "artist" who simply appropriates the style and imagery of Morriseau for her own use.

Comment: True, rail has benefits.But..
The thing about rail is that it benefits only a very tiny segment of everyone who use the H-1 at an amount which had it been spent to solve the problem of traffic congestion would have benefited everyone. Originally, the amount to be spent for the benefit of a very tiny segment of those who use the H-1 looked cheaper than solving congestion problem on the H-1. But it turns out the amount to be spent on rail far exceeds the amount that could have solved the H-1 congestion problem.
The thing about rail is that the amount spent for it far far exceeds the amount that could have accomplished traffic congestion relief on arterial streets controlled by traffic lights with installation of modern technology plus innovative redesign of street intersections.  
In short, over $9 billion would have solved H-1 congestion as well as relieve street traffic congestion.
Over $9 billion would relieve both H1 and street traffic congestion - with State consent.

Comment: That we are dumping softwood lumber is, from my understanding of the issue, a complete misrepresentation.  They cannot meet their needs without our lumber, which costs more because our trees are bigger.  In other words, their pieces of lumber are smaller and therefore costs less.  Re standing up for ourselves, softwood fights have been going on for decades; that Canada has won every WTO case ought to say it all. 

As far as dairy, their own  farmers have said in no uncertain terms that Canada is NOT the problem. The problem is they were encouraged to expand their industry and now too much milk being produced (largely by corporate farms) to the point of dumping millions of gallons of it.  In Wisconsin there are ~1200 dairy farmers; in some cases one state has more farms than all of Canada.  We are 1/10th their population, how much milk do they think we can use if they cant absorb their production? I suspect the desire is to dump their overproduction here, as opposed to downsizing.

Comment: Interesting, in reading some of the comments it would seem most are not aware that Catholic schools are part of the Alberta Act 1905 which is the legislation wherein Alberta became a province of Canada. Only the Alberta Government can elect to amend (eliminate) the provisions regarding Catholic schools.  As a side note, in two centers in Alberta the Catholic system is the public system with  Protestant Separate Schools as a compliment.

This system has worked well - the issue regarding the instruction of sex education will end up being one which accepts all people for who they are, not what they are.  This was the prevalent attitude when I formally taught in the Catholic system in Alberta.

As a side note, when I first applied to a Catholic school board, I was required to have a letter of reference from our Parish Priest.  This requirement has been pretty much replaced to any Priest/Pastor/Minister etc.  So the system is capable of accepting changes to reflect society

Comment: First Corinthians 15:35 to 50 should have established what we believe about 'the ressurection of the body.' The human body is made up of the elements of the earth, and to earth it shall return, or to fire, or to water. The remains will be eaten by worms, or fish, or birds, or mixed with the soil. The worms, the birds and the fish will be eaten by other creatures, etc. What about the organs that are donated ? Or the parts that were separated during life. The literal understanding of a permanent linking of the physical body to the immortal human soul/spirit is denied by actual facts. During life, body cells are constantly changed. To say that "God will bring together the exact scattered remains of a person" is a mechanistic image of the Divinity. Doctrine should be simple, clear, and consonant with human reality. In heaven we "shall be like the angels (Luke 21:36)," and "we shall be like {God}" (1 John 3:2). Praise God!

Comment: Fellow readers,  

Grand Chief Stewart Phillip is a conscientious, hard-working leader, not just of indigenous people, but of the many people in Canada who understand what the climate scientists and the biologists have been telling us:  that our current overuse of oil, including its transportation, severely endangers the waters, the air and the land that provide for ourselves and our children.

With respect,
Fred Bass, public health physician, scientist, father and grandfather

Comment: The clear benefits of  death with dignity in appropriate circumstances must not be allowed at the cost of facilitating unethical euthanasia. Put stronger safeguards into the bill before passing it. 

It is crucial that those who don’t want to participate in the process are allowed to refuse without retaliation.

In order to deter and detect misuse of euthanasia, there must also be a mechanism for concerned observers to make complaints if procedures are violated, if other unethical conduct occurs, or if barriers to effective care are in place.

I don’t think that the bill has any of these safeguards yet. Instead,  Baker's amendment to obscure the accuracy of death certificates would reduce the ability to identify improper use of euthanasia.

Those who dismiss stronger safeguards are either naive or self-centered.

Comment: Very well, but consider this: priests try in a special way to imitate Christ's life. Christ was celibate. Moreover, many religious live in community. It would be antithetical to their shared communal life if they did not share the vow of celibacy. Finally, it would not seem that parish priests give up sexual expression because it is demanded by the people. They do so because it is demanded by the Tradition of the Church, which seeks to carry out the will of God. Aside from centuries of celibate clergy, there is much Biblical precedence for this. Mt 19:12, Lk 20:33-35 and 1 Corinthians 7, especially verses 8-9, which touch on points mentioned here. Regarding 1 Cor 7:8-9, it is important to note that God seems to call those to the priesthood who do "practice self-control" and are not "aflame with [sexual] passion."

Finally, it is important not to be trapped in a rather recent Western paradigm that asserts, implicitly or directly, that sexual expression is necessary for happiness.

Comment: Re: VREAA's prediction being wrong, it's quite striking to note what happened to the CAD since 2012. That's when the price of oil started falling and it really went down further. What's interesting is to plot the price of Canadian places in USD or CNY for the last many years. The gains of the last five years aren't anywhere near as spectacular when viewed that way. CAD$1 went from something like US$1.08 to US$0.74 today. In the same time-frame, China instituted far greater capital controls, driving far more money out of the country.

Foreign money was always a market contributor in the Lower Mainland, but it's footprint exploded on that timeline. Prior to that, it was at least possible to pretend that people in the top 1-2% of earners could buy detached houses in the city. (Now, that's no longer the case for even those earning $225k/year without pre-existing equity, help from the bank of mom and dad, or a lottery win.)

Comment: There is already a thriving private school community in Toronto.  And if the TDSB continues its drive to mandate mediocrity and remove opportunities for kids to excel then the private system will flourish.

I started my kids in the public system.  Then moved them, at great expense, to one of the establishment single sex private schools in the city core.  These schools were of course, highly diverse, as long as you were WASP, Jewish, or Asian.  And their elitism and wealth caused its own issues - my kids were raised in an economic bubble.  But the overall quality of education, the commitment of the staff, the small class sizes, the wide range of exceptional programs, and the first class facilities were worth every penny.  You can't give your kids a better gift than a great education.  And if the TDSB, despite massive taxpayer funding, is going to elect not to provide one, then the demand for private school education will soar.  And in the end, is that good for Toronto?

Comment: Sue Steinacher - There's an economic principle - instead of looking at the short-term for a small group of people, you look at the long-term for everyone. A 6% tax today will eventually need to be a 30% tax if we maintain the same level of State government we have today. How do I know that? I attended the budget brainstorming Walker had here in Fairbanks two years ago. The math worked out that, without oil revenues, every income producer in the State would need to pay 30% tax to support the current level of government services.

So, I did the math. Currently, I wouldn't be paying much under the income tax, but I already pay 25% to the feds. In 10 years, if oil decline continues and state services remain at current levels, we will all be paying 30%. That PFD will mean nothing to me at that point because, if my income remains steady, I'll be bankrupt and living in a ditch.

Reducing the PFD for three years won't kill you and it, along with cuts, will balance the budget in five years.

Comment: The high school I attended in England is as large as any of our community college campuses. There were 2000 students in my graduating class alone. Because England graduates students at 16 years old, and with our freshman college aptitude, I had to be bumped up 2 grade levels to be with students my own age. This put me 4 years behind them as I skipped 7th grade which put me in AE, which was a cruel joke. The average class size was 30, and some went to 37. Every one of my competent teachers managed to carry their workload, and get me up to speed inside of 1 month. Most of our educators cannot teach at this level, and this is why larger class sizes hurt our system when larger class sizes assure proper funding. England was preparing me for college at 17 with the tools I would need in classes of 100+ students, and tests are how I earn a degree. I'm speaking from experience, well knowledge on Piling Higher Deeper BS.

The Standing Rock Sioux call this reservation home, and many are not on the frontlines of this months-long, and at times violent, protest. With no end in sight, what does it mean to them? And are they even united in their support?
The answer to that last question: Not even close.

Comment: As far as enforcing cell phone laws, are you aware of this Oregon Court of Appeals ruling?  I bet the police officers are.  

"In State v. Rabanales-Ramos, 273 Or App 228 (2015), the Court held that merely looking at a cell phone while driving did not violate ORS 811.507. In that case an officer stopped the defendant after observing a light coming up to the defendant’s face in the defendant’s vehicle. The officer believed the light was coming from a mobile communication device the defendant was looking down at while driving.
The Court of Appeals held the officer did not have probable cause to stop the defendant. The Court held that ORS 811.507 only prohibits using a handheld mobile communication device for voice or text communication. ORS 811.507 does not prohibit other uses of handheld mobile communication devices while driving, such as for GPS or listening to music."
How would you suggest the officer get 'probable cause' to stop someone?  I think I know one set of circumstances.

Comment: If anyone is undecided about whether to get winter tires, he or she shouldn't be.

1. Winter tires can make a significant reduction in braking distance relative to all season tires, especially if the all season tires have a performance oriented compound, as they tend to provide very poor winter traction.

2. The added cost in the wheels, installation, and possibly storage is secondary compared to the safety benefits, and the cost of an avoidable accident (e.g. insurance premiums, deductibles, repairs, injury, death).

3. Using winter tires preserves the life of your summer tires, and the condition of your summer wheels. 

I have used Nokian's "all-weather" WRG2 and WRG3 tires. They are better than all-seasons, and even better than some winter tires I have tried. They may be a good compromise for those who cannot be bothered with a winter tire change, e.g. due to storage space, cost, the limited mileage they drive or other reasons.

Comment: Your comment makes an important point and I think the problem is created by gerrymandering. This tactic has caused electoral votes in rural and less populated areas to have more weight in the final result.
Republicans receive a greater share of seats in the Congress than the votes cast for their candidates. The Democrats receive less seats than the votes cast for their candidates.
If a majority of voters support one party, but don't receive a majority of representatives, there is a disconnect between constituents and representation.
The electoral votes for the presidency are a reflection of the same problem.
Conservative commentators on this site like to point out that Justin Trudeau became PM with 39% of the vote, but they don't have a problem with Trump or Harper winning office without a majority vote.

Comment: There's  apparently little  to no evidence that government investments in innovation like this have ever increased GDP, reduced unemployment and reduced income inequality.

 Check out recent books like Robert Gordon's "The Rise and Fall  of American Growth,"  William Easterly's "The Tyranny of Experts," and Thomas Frank's "Listen Liberals." 

It's one thing to say that government R and D  led to innovations in, for example, the  internet; it's another thing to say that the internet then  increased employment and GDP and reduced income inequality. Apparently, it did not.  Indeed, economists like Robert Gordon (if I'm reading him correctly) say that the big gains in  growth and employment from hi-tech innovations are past us. 

Unless this government investment in innovation reduces unemployment,  increases GDP and reduces income inequality, the money spent is a merely a subsidy for the  special interest groups that receive it,  eg. the universities and firms they do business with.

Comment: The measure taxes on 10 brackets with flat rates for each up to $25 million.  Less than $500,000 pays $150 tax, etc..  The thrust of this discussion is how the 2.5% is applied.  The text for bracket 10 reads:  "(J) More than $25 million, the minimum tax is $30,001 plus 2.5% of the excess over $25 million." (this replaces the current laws' bracket of: "$50 million or more, but less than $75 million, the minimum tax is $50,000.").

So it's perfectly logical and theoretically correct that raising prices to cover the "cost" of the gross receipts tax elevates gross receipts eventually resulting in more tax if receipts push over a bracket limit or are already over the $25 million which triggers the 2.5% tax on the excess.

Of course price hikes will exceed the tax so that even more tax paid still results in higher profits.  Which leads us back to taxing profits without all the loopholes as fair.  Perhaps this law will force business to re-examine the current stance on taxes.

Comment: I made minimum wage in the late 80's.  Needed 2 roommates and my parents often paid for gas and upkeep on my (paid off) car.  My expenses did not include a cell phone, pay TV, or an internet connection - thank goodness!  I skipped a lot of meals.  I stood in line for commodities and did not have health insurance.  I was not aware that minimum wage ever supported a person, but I think it might have been easier back then with cheaper rents.

That being said, I was unable to get a second job at the time because I worked retail with a varied schedule. I knew other people who struggled in the same way, although my employer was more willing to give set hours to people who went to college.  It would be nice if minimum wage jobs had set hours to help people who need another job.

I am in the business of refrigeration.We just can't bled R22(which is one of the main culprits that they are referring to)into the atmosphere as it stands.Before you can buy refrigerants from a wholesaler you have to produce a ODP card which means that you are certified in the safe handling and recovery of refrigerants.  

The replacements can be Propane or Ammonia(among others). Ammonia(HN3) for example is Nitrogen and Hydrogen two "environmentally safe" chemicals but if it is released by accident it can kill(and has done). 

We in Canada are well trained in the handling of refrigerants and from working in other(most) countries that is not the case at all.The whole world should be on the same playing field.

---

Because Samsung has dominated the AMOLED mobile screen production market, Apple rather focused on higher density displays.  Lately, LG(who dominates the television space for OLEDs), has been venturing into the mobile screen space which hopefully will put pressure on Samsung to lower their prices.

Comment: You're welcome, Kenneth, but I think you missed my point.  I was responding to your statement that " it's false to say that "Native Hawaiians" have the worst statistics" by pointing out that self-identification does seem to work in the cases cited.  That is, self-identified Native Hawaiians *are* more at risk for various diseases, jail time, etc.  These are long established facts, at least since the Native Hawaiians Study Commission report of 1983.

I agree with you that it would be bad if people were self-identifying as Native Hawaiian to "get sympathy or money", but I don't believe that is the case for two reasons.  First, my experience suggests people self-identify today for reasons of pride in their Hawaiian ancestors.  Second, disease risk etc. are established statistically from large samples--it is impossible for the individual to know beforehand the outcome of a statistical test on a large sample.

Comment: Mr. Sayre trunk line fibers typically carry 40 separate 10 Gb/sec data streams multiplexed via wavelength.  PON fiber distribution networks range from 100 Mb/sec to 1 Gb/sec.  It was not revealed in the story what type of fiber distribution network is planned.  If they are putting in a DWDM network, they may provide up to 10 or in the newest systems 25 Gb/sec service.  But here is something to remember, a reasonably good hard drive has a maximum write speed of about 100 MB/s so that a computer could not keep up with saving incoming files at any fiber speed greater than about 800 Mb/sec.   Just because somebody got software companies (whose software coders often do not understand much about hardware data transport) to say they needed fiber does not mean they really do.  With cable level speeds a 1 GB file can be transferred in 6.6 seconds (approx).  Not bad.  The truth is with fiber connection my file transfers are often limited by the source site most of which gauged for cable speeds.

Comment: As a moderate person who is heavily invested financially in the  Canadian economy and wants to create wealth and health, and who carries a deep commitment to the preservation of the environment as habitat for humans and the rich diversity of other living creatures severely threatened by climate change, I believe there are alternatives to mining fossil fuels that will meet both needs - a prosperous economy and a life sustaining environment. We can invest in refining capacity to produce a fuel that is much safer to transport by pipeline. We could invest in the reduction of wasteful use of energy altogether, and invest in the development of clean energy from solar, wind, tidal and even nuclear. All these suggestions have their drawbacks. The reason they are credible alternatives to shipping bitumen to foreign ports is that we save the future of the world for our children and grandchildren, and we can start right now rather than waiting years for a pipeline and ocean port development.

Comment: Good points, all ones I like to raise in addition to one simple fact: the car is undemocratic. Could you imagine the "mighty din" that would be raised if we, one day, decided to limit huge swathes of public space based on age, economic status, and physical ability? We are already doing this and those swathes of public space are called roads. The practical reasons to ditch the car (health & well-being, pollution, road safety) are well-represented here, but rarely is it acknowledged you need to be of a certain age, physical ability, and, often, economic status to operate a car in the city - limitations that run counter to the notion of an open democratic society with "public" space.

The car has its limited uses, and personal transport is needed in a country as vast as ours. However, we all must change our mindset around the "right" to drive, especially in populated urban areas. It is time to make right and invest properly in cities, at the cost of their biggest detractors - motorists.

BTW: why did the agreement in Paris, and the preceding and subsequent agreements,  refuse to take account of the fact that Canada's forests already remove much more GHG than we are producing? We have over 10 per cent of global forests, but less than 0. 5 per cent of the global population. 2014 statistics: Canada has 318 billion trees (8,953 per person).  The US has 228 billion trees (716 per person).  Brazil had 301 billion trees (1,494 per person), China 139 billion (102 trees per person), and India 35 billion trees (28 trees per person).

Comment: The world is rarely black and white;  exceptions exist for most accepted "truths." The name Metlakatla comes to mind.  Here's a bit of what descendants have to say about that community's founder, Church of England Missionary William Duncan: 

"The title of "Father" was an honorary one given to him by a grateful and affectionate people. [His]specific mission was to Christianize ... the Tsimshian in British Columbia.  ... it was a belief that aboriginal peoples needed to be indoctrinated into Western culture ... Mr. Duncan refused to start teaching this people about the Christian Gospels until he had had the opportunity to become fluent in the language of the Tsimshians. Thereafter he stayed with the people and taught them how to exist in a world that was very different than the one to which they were accustomed.

It was a difficult feat to move from relative primitivism to a more advanced society in such a short time..." 

From Metlakatla Indian Community website

Comment: As a tax professional I can tell you that the cannibis business pays way more in taxes. Back in the 70s a drug dealer named Jeffery Edmonson actually filed a tax return (after being convicted of trafficking) for his illegal drug business. Due to that the IRS brought about the 280E. That is what is used for cannibis (even medical, physicians,retail, all of them) businesses. Under the 280E about 80% of the normal deductions a business can take are not allowed resulting in an extremely higher taxable income. The cannibis industry pays a very large amount more than any other industry. This article has a great explanation of it.

Comment: The globe should review their own reporting on Jumbo. Stating that the "BC government gave permission in 2012 for the development to go ahead" is wrong.

Jumbo was given the go ahead (an Environmental Certificate, EC) in 2004 but did nothing. In 2009 they were given a one time 5 year EC extension. In 2014 during the dying moments of the EC the Jumbo developers poured two concrete pseudo-foundations in the upper Jumbo valley - both were in locations exposed to avalanches and this rendered them unusable. At that point the EC expired, no renewal possible. In 2015 the BC Government determined that no substantial start to the project had occurred and therefore the project was dead. Arriving at that decision caused the supporters within the BC gov (B. Bennett) great pain but they could not avoid it because the developer had made such an egregious mess of the whole project.

Note: in 2012 the BC Liberals created the municipality of Jumbo, a town with no residents, no road, no buildings.

Comment: There is a bottom for the price of gasoline - or anything, for that matter - since there's a limit to how far you can cut costs and still be able to produce your product.  $.95 is almost surely below that point, but I could see it falling to the $1.50 area.

There's certainly pros and cons to both ICE and EV.  Up until now, the edge has clearly been to the ICE side (giving it something like 98% of all vehicle sales).  We agree that EVs are improving enough to cause a shift, possibly a rather dramatic shift, in the coming years.  But there's still some key drawbacks that have yet to be overcome, namely refueling and range, that will slow that shift down until they're solved.

But even a 10% market share by 2025 would still be a dramatic shift with continued growth on the horizon.  I think something like that could be a realistic target.

Comment: Here is a simple hypothetical example of how it could work.  Consider needing a test that medical protocols say should be done within 3 months.  The public system continues to function within that protocol (i.e. standards can't be allowed to fall), but as a patient I want to do to the test today and incur a cost to do it.  This gives me what I want, it frees up resources on the public program, and a patient on the public system now has one less person on the list in front of them, thereby reducing the time they need to wait.  If done well, this is a win win for all.

This is highly complex, but it could be done.

Comment: Competitiveness of our oil sector with the US oil sector is a bit of a red herring.  

Right now there is no sense in increasing our output by much until we have pipelines to get it to markets other than the US. Our primary output now comes from the oil sands and we do not have the pipeline capacity for it (excluding  rail which is much more expensive and environmentally unsafe). 

The US shale oil is a different, lighter grade than Canadian oil which tends toward heavy. Hence they are not in direct competition since refineries are configured to take prodominantly one or the other And cannot interchange their inputs at will.

As to opening up new areas for oil exploration, that could be problematic given the protests we see over pipelines.

Comment: Teaching children programming using a well designed, interactive language can give kids a basic, intuitive understanding of algebra years before they ever open an algebra text book. Teach a child coding and they gain an intuitive understanding of concepts like functions, variables, recursion, etc., and and they will develop critical thinking skills that allow them to break down problems in to constituent parts and solve them in a sensible order. In short, they will gain familiarity with mathematical processes. Sure, some of them might develop a liking for it, just as some kids develop a liking for history, but that's missing the point. The point is not to create new 'coders,' the point is to give them a leg up when they start learning algebra, so when they are introduced to new concepts they can say "oh, hey I've seen something like this before."

Coding is the one of the best tools we've ever come up with for early math education. As always, the effectiveness depends on the teacher.

Comment: Kingwell cautions against a facile, self-satisfied assumption regarding Canada’s virtue.  There’s a broader context.

We’re shaped by uncommon conditions.  We rarely face hostile forces at our borders but live in the shadow of the US and earlier the UK.  We have no dominant cultural group but have had at least two such groups claiming the right to pre-eminence or autonomy during our history.  We are a geographically dispersed society with an urban-rural divide. Etc.

 Consequently, domestic attitudes have swung between two two poles over time but often strike an equitable middle balance.  One is the exceptionalism of the article.  

The other is a depressed reactionary exclusionary miasma that occasionally dominates a region or cultural group and sometimes Canada as a whole. Think of the Orange Order and its Catholic counterparts during the 19th and early 20th century (and also more recent examples).  Isn’t this analogous to the factors that birthed the Trump Presidency?

Comment: The district has a few distinct health plans. One for bus drivers and attendants, one for teachers (which is part of a statewide plan for all teachers), and one for all of the other bargaining units. This includes TOTEM (TAs and secretaries/clerical), ACE (technical//supervisory, security, etc.), APA (principals and assistant principals), food service, maintenance and warehouse, exempt employees (school board, superintendent, other high-level district administrators and their staff). They're all on the same health insurance plan, so they are all covered  under the clinic. That's also why the other bargaining units aren't, as their health care dollars are separate. If it's successful, hopefully it can be expanded.

It isn't really a perk so much as another option, to hopefully lower costs and get services down closer to their actual cost. It isn't going to necessarily be free, but these types of clinics aren't for-profit, so that should drive down costs for the district and employee.

Comment: A rather crude mis-analogy. In that situation, a person who is drinking can take steps prior to becoming impaired so resolve the situation, i.e. they can take their keys and remove them from their person, or arrange another route home ahead of time. 

In the case of sexual assault, it takes two to tango. It is reasonable for the law to state that someone who is incapacitated from alcohol cannot give consent for sexual activity to another person, and that other person has the responsibility to obtain knowing consent. 

What happens if the other person cannot tell if the 'victim' is incapacitated? What happens if both parties are intoxicated? Good questions, requiring the application of judgment and context in the legal system. But it doesn't violate a general premise that those who are intoxicated are incapable of giving their consent to sexual activity with another and are victims, but nonetheless must be held responsible for driving while impaired.

Comment: I remember when a 22 car derailment burned for the greater part of a week within 12 miles of our house in Lowell Oregon, and all roads in and out of town were blocked: Northshore Drive (Pengra) was blocked by accidents of trucks trying to take alternative routes, while Hwy 58 was blocked by authorities both at the MP 14 and MP 12.  The cargo was nominally "methanol," but it tested out as varnish solvent, including MEK--methyl ethyl ketone.   The emergency agancies didn't know what the hell methanol was, and even if it it was water soluble or not.  DEQ, and most state agencies, were AWAL.  DEQ "analyses" declared that the spill did not contain flammable solvents--actually these were repackaged analyses of the RR consultants.  Nevertheless, the "non-flammable solvents" burned for the greater part of a week--as observed by residents.   The RR (then SP) sent out its legal team:  the SP counsel informed me that people south of 58 claiming methanol in their wells "practiced witchcraft."

Comment: It is trues that God needs nothing from us than to be ourselves. BUT what does it mean to "be ourselves"? In the Nicomachean Ethics, Aristotle uses the word εὐδαιμονία (eudiamonia) to talk about the final end of human beings. It is often translated "happiness" but better translated as "human flourishing." This is quite literally the state of a human person being fully what it is. The ethical project is about becoming oneself. How does one do this? Only by developing virtues like temperance, courage, prudence, generosity, justice, ect.  This fits well into a Christian context since Christ said that sin enslaves us to itself. Virtues are the by which we free ourselves to become ourselves to the highest degree possible. So, in other words, ethics is not about changing who we are, but making us more of what we are.

Comment: So where do you live?
Do you live on acreage covered in trees as I do?
Have you been evacuated 4 of the past 10 years, as I have?
Do you actually attend municipal and provincial meetings regarding fire fuel remediation, as I do?

I didn't think so.

You can not let fires simply burn when they are in close proximity to human habitation.  Sure, in desolate areas, let them burn, as they already do, and have done for decades.  Within 1 km of human habitation, the only preventative action is to remove deadfalls and dead standing wood, as every municipality in BC does, and has done for decades.

The problem is crown land (administered by the provincial government of the day) which is located within municipal limits.  Municipalities across BC have made requests ( and been denied) funding to address this key issue.  No one is suggesting that dead wood should be removed from forests located away from human habitation.

Perhaps you should comment on things you actually know something about.

Comment: My sense is that Morneau is right. 

There are sufficient fair vehicles and tools for responsible accounting, but historically businesses have been used to getting a pretty good deal when it comes to taxes. So much so that any multi-level marketer worth their salt promotes the tax-savings incentives first over any possible hope of making an income on sales.

Real businesses should not need tax incentives. They are way down on the list of what firms look for. What is important for a real firm is a skilled workforce,  good infrastructure, and the rule of law. The profit motive is there as well, but it's likely Morneau is talking economic profit, and those complaining about the taxes are concerned over accounting profits.

And BOOM! I sure liked his closing comments!

Comment: Dennis Callahan -  "Synchronized" lights is the old way of speeding up street traffic.
The modern way of speeding up street traffic is "Adaptive Signal Control Technology"  or ASCT . (http://www.fhwa.dot.gov/everydaycounts/technology/adsc/)
"The traditional signal timing process is time consuming and requires substantial amounts of manually collected traffic data. Traditional Time-of-Day signal timing plans do not accommodate variable and unpredictable traffic demands.......With ASCT, information is collected and signal timing is updated continually."
"The main benefits of adaptive signal control technology over conventional signal systems are that it can:
    * Continuously distribute green light time equitably for all traffic movements
    * Improve travel time reliability by progressively moving vehicles through green lights
    * Reduce congestion by creating smoother flow
    * Prolong the effectiveness of traffic signal timing"

Comment: Enforcement first -- then you can talk about Amnesty.

Books have been written about this, but here's the quick summary:

1. Most importantly: The problem with amnesty is that you are holding up a gigantic flashing sign to Central and South America. The sign says: "Sneak into the U.S.! Sure, they'll talk tough, but the bottom line is, if you just hold on long enough, they'll let you stay! It happened in the 80s, it happened in the 2000s, and it will happen again!"
2. It also validates hundreds of thousands of people who broke the law over those who actually followed the law.
3. Agreeing for amnesty in return for *promises of future enforcement* is a swindler's game. The people who offer such promises know full well that their "promises" are worthless -- they will be tied up in court, circumvented via the bureaucracy, not enforced, etc.

"Comprehensive Reform" is a gigantic, bipartisan scam. We don't need or want it. We need enforcement first. Everything else can be settled later.

Comment: Yes.  There is a great need to revisit the stories on which much of our faith is based, certainly the basic Garden of Eden stories, ideas of original sin, ideas of what is a sin, the idea that the Jewish faithful were more precious to God than all others He imbued with human life, the idea that the Bible is God's Word, rather than the wisdom of the ages and the cultures in which the stories were written.  

We need a mythology and philosophy that recognizes we evolved and are evolving, that we cannot "know" God, even though He put a yearning in our minds and hearts to seek Him.   We have to be able to admit we can only find some aspect of God in imperfect forms of metaphor and allegory and we need to be able to take new knowledge and adapt/change/create the metaphor and allegory that reflects our new understandings.  In other words, there is no infallible-for-all-time dogma.  

We need to learn to be humble.  Some need that lesson rather badly.

Comment: Precisely - road usage is discretionary, and should follow the "user pays" principle (with a corresponding reduction in taxes). Why should I, who take the bus everywhere, pay for road space for your car? Especially when the space taken up by your car could accommodate 8-12 people like me in the bus? 
Tax financing should be used for insurance-like purposes - healthcare for example. We do not choose whether to have a heart attack, and our ability to survive it should not be linked to our ability to pay. Tax financing of medical services serves an insurance function. We do however choose when and how to use the road. Shifting those costs to other taxpayers is unfair.

Comment: Just because Hydro claims Site C's power is inexpensive doesn't make it so.  Don't be fooled by the "free" water.   Nat. gas would have been far cheaper.  Calgary recently built a gas power plant for $1.4 billion that produces more energy (6,500 GWh/yr) than Site C.   The annual fuel cost is a fraction of the yearly interest paid on a $10 billion loan.

By example, would you buy a $250,000 car that ran on water and lasts 100 years instead of a $25,000 car that burned gas and lasts 20 years?  Especially if the gas cost $2,000/yr but the interest on a $250,000 loan was $10,000/yr?  And what if I told you the $250 K car may end up costing $400 K, but when you find this out you'll be on the hook for $100 K which you won't get back.  And that it will take you 70 years to pay off the $250 K car, but changing technology will make the car obsolete in 20 years.   How stupid Hydro's Site C financial justification is.  Just ask Newfoundland about the disastrous Muskrat Falls hydro project.

Comment: If you read the reasons carefully, the judge is relying on a theory that the complainant was able to consent right until the point that she was unconscious.  Though I have little experience of people passing out drunk, in cases I have witnessed, they are obviously not competent in the minutes leading up to passing out.  It isn't an instantaneous change. Indeed, the law is that someone can be incapacitated by alcohol and unable to consent before the point of being unconscious -- surely the minutes before passing out would be that degree of incapacity.  

Also note the judge specifically stated that the arrest and charges were justified given the circumstantial evidence that suggested there was an assault (and Blatchford's shock that he then contends that no evidence of assault was presented).  

The Crown is obliged to drop charges if they deem there is no possibility of conviction, not just because they think they might not win.  The latter would be to allow the Crown to be the judge.
