Comment: The classically liberal approach to social issues was to challenge traditional conservative beliefs: Christians good, non-Christians bad; men strong, women weak; straight good, gay bad, etc. Liberalism (again, in the classic sense) says these group identities have no place in the public sphere, and should be given no legal recognition. A citizens is a citizen is a citizen. A woman has every right that a man has, a gay person has every right a straight person has, etc. That's why it was liberalism that fought the racist and sexist behaviours that were normal in decades past. 

But the left is no longer motivated by liberalism. Instead, they've turned to cultural Marxism. Under that model, it's groups that matter, not individuals. We shouldn't ignore that someone is a woman, or Asian, or Catholic, or Muslim. Those identities should actually be our main social role, and balancing the outcomes of those groups the goal of justice.

Very different ways of looking at the world.

Comment: My father was misdiagnosed with stomach flu when in fact his illness was stomach ulcers.  His Dr.'s advice of take aspirin and stay in bed worsened the condition rapidly leading to major surgery and colostomy.  He was 35.  

I had one hip replaced last year at St. Mike's. My surgeon broke my femur AND my pelvis, something virtually unheard of.  The blame was laid specifically my weak bones.  Turns out (no surprise) aside from me wearing my hips out prematurely the problem isn't mine.  My bone density is of a much younger man. The problem was a prosthesis that was too large. I have a hip filled with metal screws, plates and bands.

My wife had exploratory surgery at Mt. Sinai for abdominal tumors, as per x-rays.  Afterwards, the surgeon berated her in the recovery room for wasting hospital resources since there was nothing wrong with her.  A few short years later, a Dr. at Sunnybrook removed 5 very large but thankfully benign tumors.

Lesson, don't believe everything Dr.'s tell you.

Comment: Here is some more high school level physics.
Since the heat capacity of sea water is a lot higher than air above it. The planet is about 70% covered by water .The sea water drives the atmospheric temperature ,not the other way around.
air @ 1158 J/(kg*C)   sea water @3850 J/(kg*C)
When you figure in the total mass of the oceans compared to the atmosphere  , the ocean has a 1000X's the heat capacity of the atmosphere.
The top 3.2m of the worlds oceans has the same heat capacity of the entire atmosphere.
So what drives the oceans temp.'s , that would be solar energy from the sun.It penetrates deep enough for warming down to 100m to 200m , that's well beyond the 3.2m level . Atmospheric CO2 , man made or other wise(via claims of AGW) has nothing to do with it.
see:http://eesc.columbia.edu/courses/ees/climate/lectures/o_atm.html ocean-atmospheric coupling
see:http://www.geo.arizona.edu/geo4xx/geos412/OcSci07.PhysProps.pdf

Comment: The point is not the inflation adjustment in the future - the point is that typically the civil service wage is a lot higher than what the same job pays in the private sector.  The disparity gets even wider when benefits and (especially) pensions are considered.  A 3-year freeze, for example, is not even a very severe measure when you start out 25% ahead.  That might let the private workers close up, say, one quarter of the gap.  So I will shed no tears for the union head.
It is true, however, that the managerial ranks, especially in the medical area, are even more overpaid than the rank-and-file union staff.  So how about a "progressive" pay cut?  15% above $200k, zero at $40k, and a sliding scale in between.  The more you make, the bigger the (%) cut.   That would preserve as much as possible of spending and jobs, while seriously denting the budget deficit.

Comment: Andrew,

This is a poorly thought out column. You start with a claim that investors specifically in factor-based indexes take bigger risks, but end up with "Those who wish to beat the market often jump around. They chase past winners." which is a reflection of a type of investor behaviour not of any risk particular to factor-based funds. Second, the performance comparisons you cite are flawed in that they do not consider the relative volatility of each fund's returns. Whether the particular funds were actually better or worse bets than passive indexing would depend on their Sharpe/Sortino ratios and whether the investor was able to appreciate that the returns would not correlate 100% to an index benchmark. Ultimately all you've demonstrated is the tautology that those who choose bigger risks face bigger risks, which is hardly a novel observation. You also haven't identified  the risks index investors took during the sample period that didn't materialize but might in future returns.

Comment: Yes, I assume it is. The Royal Commission’s role is to identify factors in institutions that contributed to the sexual abuse of children. It found that easy forgiveness in confession encouraged recidivism. The Commission recognized that the Catholic Church is not the only religion that has this problem, but the evidence mainly came from Catholic case studies and those who treated such priests. A civil reporting law and a canonical prohibition of absolution can work together to discourage this use (or abuse) of the sacrament.  A civil reporting law is useless if the confessor doesn’t know who the penitent is. A canonical prohibition, if widely publicized, will be much more effective because the abuser will know that it is pointless going to confession if he knows that absolution will be refused until he hands himself in. That’s why a change in canon law is so important.

Comment: Repulsive as it is to say I actually agree with Traini on this one. I know everyone on here is going to be pro Uber because they think they can get a ride from Talkeetna to the airport for $5, but please keep a few things in mind. Taxi regs e.g. driver background checks, licensing and video cameras were implemented in response to high profile sexual assaults and robberies of passengers and drivers. These should be kept in place and not subject to Uber's "disruption" aka ignoring laws they find inconvenient. 
Uber treats its drivers terribly, often coercing them to take out above market rate loans for vehicles based on unrealistic promises of income. It provides no workers compensation, health insurance or other benefits to drivers. The whole company is essentially a scheme to evade labor laws and taxi regulations. Only  42% of Uber's costs are covered by fares, the rest subsidized by investors. Bet that once they drive the regulated taxis out of business those $5 fares will skyrocket.

Comment: The first thing people need to realize is that Trump's tax plan doesn't add up, given his other initiatives.     In fact, it points to a huge increase in their deficit and a huge increase in debt.    Combine that with Trump's protectionist rhetoric.     It sounds really great to bring back jobs to the U.S., but with that comes higher costs which WILL be passed on to the consumers.   Then there's healthcare costs.

The second thing people need to know is what's involved in moving to the U.S. and what the long-term implications are from a tax perspective.    I've worked in the U.S. so know a little bit about it.    As a green-card holder, you can work for up to 7 years.     After that, you will be subject to the U.S. Exit taxes which are prohibitively high.     The only way to avoid that is to move back before, or take out U.S. citizenship.     U.S. citizenship means that you will have universal taxation as long as you remain a citizen, be subject to US Estate taxes, etc

Comment: First we have to define what is a need and what is a want and then we need to decide if government is the only one capable of providing that legitimate need. Roads and airfields in roadless communities are a need. Schools are a want. We live in an internet-based world and school could be handled through it and frankly, could be handled better by a private organization at much less than the government would spend.

But do roads need to be built by the government? Well, they aren't built by the government now. They're built by private companies working under contract to the government. Road service districts in Fairbanks already exist who would collect the service fees and contract with private companies for road maintenance.

So, when we talk about "shared needs" and an income tax, we need to be very ruthless in our definitions because high-tax states generally are states that are losing population and the fewer people you have, the higher taxes will go.

Comment: It's almost certainly coming but it ain't here yet. 

"The Model X claims a summer range of 475 kilometres "  The winter range is curiously absent, and for those of us in the snow belt that have become accustomed to such luxuries as a windshield you can see through and in-vehicle temperatures that allow for the drinking of liquids, my guess is that it is on the order of 60% of that figure.

I like road trips any time of year.  Even 475 kilometres won't cut it for me unless I can recharge in less than 20 minutes -- and don't have to search high and low for a station.

I also have concerns about the ability of the power grid to handle the demand.  Ontario has nearly 7M cars on the road.  Can we really generate enough moderately clean power to charge them all?

Major investment will be required.  It took decades to create the infrastructure needed to efficiently handle the demands of the internal combustion engine.  Decades will be needed to make EVs mainstream.

Comment: The US military discriminates against people by age (I believe 40 is the maximum enrollment age for basic training). So it is ageist. 

The US military discriminates based on physical capabilities foo all kinds. So it is ableist. 

The US military discriminates on the basis of intelligence, height, weight, and against a vast plethora of medical conditions. 

There are arguments on both sides of this trans issue, but there is a perfectly reasonable and I think strong argument for the ban - the argument being that transgendered people, in addition to burdening the military medical system with additional medical costs, also have statistically far higher rates of depression and anxiety disorders than the general population. Some perfectly healthy and able trans people will be discriminated against, just as some over-40 people who *could* pass basic training are discriminated against. It is not always fair and equitable but the military is not a college campus, it is a killing machine.

Comment: Re: Solyndra, spot-picking right-wingers such as Will still love to trot out this tired old topic. They use that event as an excuse to re-state the claim that the “free market” does a better job of allocating development capital than a government institution ever can. (Never mind that the Chinese government had specifically begun to directly subsidize the production of solar panels at essentially that very same time.) With regards to that claim, I ask the following four questions.

1) Did it ever occur to the wags that -- since many more ventures backed by the “free markets” fail than do succeed, and that to call this “good” because it winnows out the losers -- it is hypocritical to apply a “no failures rule” ONLY when a government-backed venture fails?

2) Did it ever occur to these same wags that many of our renewable energy ventures fail, or lose ground to those from other countries, because those other countries heavily subsidize them, almost as a matter of necessity?

Comment: The suggestions in this article are constructive ones, however, they will, sadly, fail for a lot of people if one important factor is not addressed,..the possibility of one or more significant nutritional deficiencies.

Addressing deficiency means the body is not crying out for nutrition and seeking what it lacks however it can.   There is a condition called pica which is a specific form of this condition typically related to iron deficiency.   Also, a lot of women crave certain foods during pregnancy they would not otherwise want to eat.   

I'm not sure why medical science accepts nutritional deficiency as the basis for medical conditions in these specific cases (pica, pregnancy related cravings), and rejects it as a possible contributor to overeating and weight gain.   The only conclusion I can draw is there is not enough profit in it.

Comment: Schnurr writes that CPI-common: “which the central bank says is the best gauge of the economy’s underperformance, held at 1.3 per cent”. The Bank of Canada has shown a preference for CPI-common as its core inflation measure over the other two measures that now make up its operational guide, more it would seem, because for a long time it showed lower inflation rates than any other measure than due to any inherent advantages. However a core inflation measure is not equivalent to a gauge of the economy’s underperformance, and even the Bank of Canada never suggested it was. In fact its technical box on “New measures of core inflation” claims that the new core measures are to be preferred to CPIX because of an alleged stronger “peak correlation between the output gap at time t and the core inflation measure x quarters later [t + x],” where x is between two and seven.

Comment: Canadians shouldn't think that the dark undercurrents at play on the political stages in the countries discussed in this article are not at play in Canada.  Under our first-past-the-post electoral system, it is difficult for a charismatic demagogue to emerge as a significant player in Federal politics by rallying an anxious, angry, outcast following with a message that scapegoats foreigners and minorities. Is isn't that Canada doesn't have such anxious, angry, outcasts and wannabe demagogic leaders; only that it is very difficult for Parties focussed upon these features to gain the more than 20% electorate support that is needed here to become a real player for power.

By contrast, under a proportional representation or certain ranked ballot electoral systems like those in the countries discussed in this article,  10% or so support however scattered across a country makes such a Party a player and 20% or more makes it a contender for real power.

Comment: I don't really see any proposal for a solution in the article. Although I think the contribution of foreign investment is being underestimated, I do agree there is a supply issue.  Take for example recent data from Metro Vancouver - 80% of residential land houses only 35% of the population. That's a supply management problem. The solution is not simply to allow urban sprawl. That brings a host of other issues such as poor transportation, poor public services and high crime. A better approach to the supply issue rezoning and re-balance the above land use ratio (urban density). Detached homes will become rare and more expensive, but affordable options like townhouse will be in greater supply and more affordable. For example, duplexes in Vancouver are now >$1M! because of supply does not meet demand. Canada's largest cities will need to ween themselves off the detached house.

Comment: My grandparents immigrated from Mexico when my mother was 10. They did it "The Right Way"; piles of forms, probationary period, citizenship classes and tests, and then the swearing in type ceremony. My grandmother has told me many times that it was her proudest moment in life. I was dead-set against the Trumpser ending the DACA program because I have several family members who are enrolled. When my grandmother announced that she was "glad it's ending" I was totally speechless. Until she explained. She told me that she had earned her citizenship. She worked for it, studied her butt off in her classes, and aced the final test. She worked for it. She compared it to a kid who studies hard, does his assignments, and gives up her playtime so she can get an A. Then the teacher just gifts an A to another kid who did nothing to earn it because it's not "fair". She feels like DACA is a slap in the face to every immigrant who did it right and earned their citizenship.

Comment: News Flash! CO2 is not a pollutant. It’s a colorless, odorless gas which is essential for life on our resilient planet.

Measuring CO2 emissions per capita is meaningless, but most sources say the USA is between 8th and 10th per capita.

Comment: I am not a miner, but as I understand it, mercury in its natural state is most often found as  red mineral called cinnabar which is 'roasted' to get liquid mercury.  However, much of the sluice mining is done downstream from gold mines developed during the gold rush days.  The Bohemia area near Cottage Grove, for example.  Since miners of the time used liquid mercury to help remove gold from their finds, much liquid mercury was lost and found its way downstream.  Here's a site from the government:  http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2005/3014/

Comment: State pensions are in trouble mostly because all defined benefit plans are in trouble.  The benefit is thirty years and out with the pension based on the highest three years of salary.  Add in low contribution rates and wildly optimistic earnings projections and you see what happens.  The only pension plans that work are defined contribution plans based on years of service, money actually contributed, realistic rate of return, and no health care benefit from the pension.  The unions wanted pensions and this is what poor state management got them and the taxpayer.

Comment: The filibuster has nothing to do with democracy.  It has to do with protection of Senate incumbents.

It has to do with the power of individual incumbent senators - who all fear that being in the minority will hurt their ability to "bring home the bacon" to their home state - eliminating a big part of the edge incumbents have in seeking re-election.

Unfortunately, they will still be able to retain much power in keeping the goodies flowing to the home folks - even though that flow leads to huge budget deficits - an ocean of red-ink far more likely to flood the land of America than any rising tide from global climate change.

The rest of the filibuster rule should be eliminated immediately - especially as regards spending bills.

We have had a Congress unable to act - unable to govern - for years and decades.  The filibuster is not the only reason, but its effect is huge.

This is a step away from gridlock.  May there be more steps to come.

Comment: I'd rather cite the Limits to Growth than Wikipedia ...

Limits to growth predicted peak resources (not only oil) around the turn of the century.  They cautioned not to fixate on any precise date, since there are many variables that alter the curves of use / depletion.

They also predicted peak pollution would come after peak extraction.  We are having this with fracking and tar sands (lower quality resources that are  dirtier than crude oil from conventional wells).  Fracking is a short term boom and bust.

The study ran a scenario assuming twice as much resource which predicted that would push the peak back a little but not change the ultimate outcome.  Exponential growth!

In the 1970s, M. King Hubbert predicted global peak would be in the 1990s but this might get delayed a decade with conservation efforts, which is what happened.  Conventional peak was around 2006. 

Most of the "green left" these days is pushing "green growth," not limits to growth.

Comment: To those of whom do not understand Our Native Culture: Indegenous People have their rights to hunt for their game. To feed their families. Keep their cultures alive. Indigenous people are people defined in international or national legislation as having a set of specific rights based on their historical ties to a particular territory, and their cultural or historical distinctiveness from other populations that are often politically dominant.Jan 2, 2017

Comment: "A continuing Globe investigation has traced the roots of Canada's opioid epidemic to the introduction in 1996 of OxyContin, a prescription painkiller made by Purdue."

Oxy exacerbated the epidemic, however it goes back much further. Research methadone maintenance in Canada it goes back to the 1970's. Canada was a leader in fighting the opioid epidemic back in those days.

By the 1980's methadone maintenance was mainstream. Also the 1980's brought the advent of the triplicate prescription programs designed to assist doctors to manage the long ongoing epidemic.

The ongoing war against doctors and big pharma has more to do with the war against capitalism than it does with the war against addiction.

It is not black and white like the G&M wants you to believe. There is a long, nuanced history that is being ignored  for political reasons.

Interestingly, it was as much a political debate in 1974 as it is today.

Comment: "No no no. If you write something (other than libel or slander) and someone doesn't like it, tough."

From one perspective, I get it. It's my art.

From another perspective ... why wouldn't I incorporate critique, suggestions, etc. into my work to make it stronger where I'm currently weak? How is telling me that my Asian characters are a little stereotypical any worse for me or my writing than my editor telling me I overuse a repetitive sentence structure?  

If my goal is to become a better writer over time, I'd best be open to learning, no?
